docs.text: Pootis-Bot Welcome to the Pootis-Bot docs. Click here to download Pootis-Bot Bot Features Some current features that the bot can do. More feature are planed to be added Multi Server Capabilities Moderation User Accounts Music Service (Plays from YouTube) Google, YouTube and Giphy search support Auto Voice Channels Notes Pootis-Bot is an open-source Discord Bot using Discord.NET licensed under the MIT license . I will not host the bot for you, you will have to host the bot yourself! If you want to host the bot your self for public use you can, though Pootis-Bot was designed for MY server, but it is multi servers compatible. I also recommend that you disable the audio services due to the fact that the audio services use a lot of resources and are a fairly experimental feature. Quick Links Here are some quick links Building Pootis-Bot for your self. Pootis-Bot Discord commands Setup Pootis-Bot for you server

docs.text: Everything in the Server Setup section should help you get Pootis-Bot working for your server! Setting up Pootis-Bot for your server Note All commands that are contained in the server setup section require to be ran by the server's owner! At anytime you can run the command setup to get a detailed info about your server and its setup status. Important commands These commands are all quite powerful and should have a permission added onto them . Command Summary warn Warns a user. When the warning count gets to three they are kicked from the server, and when it reaches four they are baned. makewarnable Allows a user to be made warn-able. makenotwarnable Allows a user to be not warn-able. kick Kicks a user. ban Bans a user. addvcchannel Adds a auto-vc channel . Useful features These features are quite useful but are not required. Rule Reaction System | Makes a newly joined user have to react to a message before allowed access to the rest of the server. Can help stop spam, and spam bots. Welcome & Goodbye message | Allows the use of a custom welcome message and goodbye message for when a user joins/leaves. Auto Voice Channels | Can make your Discord server's voice channels look at lot cleaner.

docs.text: Building Pootis-Bot These instructions should help you build Pootis-Bot. If already know how to build for Dotnet Core then you should be fine and probably don't have to read this. Prerequisites .NET Core 2 .2 SDK How to build on Windows First head to the main directory of Pootis-Bot. Where the Pootis-Bot.sln file is. Then go into the Build folder. In this folder you should see 4 bat files: Publish_Linux-x64.bat Publish_MacOS-x64.bat Publish_Win-x64.bat Publish_Win-x86.bat Run one of theses bat file for your os of choice. Example: Building for Windows 64-Bit you would run the Publish_Win-x64.bat file. How to build on not Windows Navigate to where the Pootis-Bot.csproj file is. Open the terminal and run the command: dotnet publish -c Release -r [RID] Where the [RID] replace it with something from this list . You can use any OS.
docs.title: Building Pootis-Bot

docs.text: Config File Here is a overview of the config file. This is for config version: 2, Pootis-Bot version: 0.2.6. Updated 22/07/19 Default config { "configVersion" : "2" , "botToken" : "" , "botPrefix" : "$" , "botName" : "Bot" , "twichStreamingSite" : "https://www.twitch.tv/creepysin" , "gameMessage" : "Use $help for help." , "isAudioServiceEnabled" : false , "checkConnectionStatus" : true , "checkConnectionStatusInterval" : 60000 , "apis" : { "apiGiphyKey" : null , "apiYoutubeKey" : null , "apiGoogleSearchKey" : null , "googleSearchEngineID" : null }, "helpModules" : [ { "group" : "Basic" , "modules" : [ "BasicCommands" , "Misc" ] }, { "group" : "Utils" , "modules" : [ "Utils" ] }, { "group" : "Fun" , "modules" : [ "GiphySearch" , "GoogleSearch" , "YoutubeSearch" , "TronaldDump" ] }, { "group" : "Audio" , "modules" : [ "Music" ] } ] } Notice A lot of these options are in the bot's config menu, If you want to access the bot's config menu, run the command config in the console. What does each key mean? General Options configVersion - The config's version, its best to leave this alone since it is only used if the bot's config is updated and it needs to be saved again. botToken - The bot's token, you can set this in the config menu. botPrefix - What prefix to use, you can set this in the config menu. botName - The bot's name, you can set this in the config menu. twichStreamingSite - If bot is in streaming mode, what Twitch site should it show, by default it set to mine. gameMessage - Default game message, in case the bot restarts it will default to this. isAudioServiceEnabled - Are audio services enabled. checkConnectionStatus - Checks connection status every so often. checkConnectionStatusInterval - How often to check the connection status, in milliseconds. API Keys All of these can be set in the config menu under apis . apiGiphyKey - Giphy api key. apiYoutubeKey - YouTube api key. apiGoogleSearchKey - Google Search api key. googleSearchEngineID - Google Search Engine ID. Help Modules Each help module is structured like this: { "group" : "[GROUP NAME]" , "modules" : [ "[MODULE NAME]" ] } Group - Refers to the name of group in each help section modules - Has a list of all the modules you want to include in that section.
docs.title: Config File

docs.text: Anti Spam Pootis-Bot includes some anti-spam features. General Commands Command Summary setup spam Shows setup info regarding the server's anti-spam settings. Mass Ping Anti-Spam Do you have bots/users/trolls coming onto your Discord server and pinging everyone's name in one long message? Well Pootis-Bot can counter that! If a user pings more then x % amount of users on the server then the message will be deleted. This is mainly a problem with bigger servers but anyway its still a good idea to have this enabled. Commands Command Summary Default togglementionuser Enables / Disables the mention user anti-spam feature enabled setmentionuserthreshold [threshold] Set how much of a percentage of a servers users need to be mention before it is considered spam 45 Role to Role Ping Don't want a user with a certain role to be able to ping a role? Once again Pootis-Bot can also counter that. If user x that has the g role tries to ping the 8 role, their message will be deleted, if they try to continue to ping the same role they will receive a warning. This is good if you have a role that you may only want admins to ping. Commands Command Summary addroleping [role not to mention] [role] Prevents [role not to mention] pinging [role] . removeroleping [role not to mention] [role] Does the opposite of addroleping .
docs.title: Anti Spam

docs.text: Auto Voice Channels What are auto voice channels? Auto voice channels initially look like this: And when you connect to one it then looks like this: Basically when you connect to the new VC voice chat it creates a new voice chat and moves you there. After everyone has disconnected from that voice chat it is then deleted. Video showcase See here: https://youtu.be/5i8Ihz0fqKw How to setup To create an auto voice channel is easy, run the command: addvcchannel [ Base Name ] It will then add a voice channel and you can move it to were ever you want it to be! To delete it, just delete it like a normal voice channel.

docs.text: Permission System Pootis Bot includes a permission system that allows you to have a specific role(s) for a command. Adding a permission You can set a permission for a command using this command: perm [Command] add [Role] The [Command] part can be any command that is not on this list . Example perm youtube add Admin This would make the command youtube only accessible by users with the role Admin. Removing a permission Removing a permission is simple, type: perm [Command] remove [Role] This will remove the permission. Commands you can't add You cannot add a permission to these commands for reasons: profile profilemsg hello ping perm
docs.title: Permission System

docs.text: Rule Reaction System Pootis-Bot comes with a rule reaction system. Example: A new user would join your server but they would have to first react to a message with a specific emoji. Setup Message First off you would need a message. This message can be from anyone in any channel. It can even be a embed message say from the command embed that bot features. It is recommend to have this message in its own channel such as a #rules channel that basically any public server has, with permission that no on (except you of course) can write to it, but can still react in it (important). Now you need to get the message ID. Follow this guide to learn how get into developer mode. Hover over the message you want to get the ID of, then next to were you would react to a message, click on on the three little dots -> Copy ID. Here what it should look like. Once you got that ID of the message you want to use, run the command: setuprulesmessage [ID] But instead of [ID] you would put the ID we copied. Example: setuprulesmessage 487951616666763274 Choosing an emoji Once you have done that now its time for our emoji. Go to this site and pick out an emoji. For this example I will choose 😄(grinning face with smiling eyes) After that you need to run setupruleemoji [emoji] So mine would be setupruleemoji 😄 The emoji can't be the one in the Discord format, it must be unicode! 😄 would actually be :simle: in Discord but due to way the bot works :simle: won't work! The bot does check for this and will tell you! It is all so a good idea to put in that message that you need to react to this message with this emoji. E.G: React with 😄 to gain access to the server once you have read the rules! Setting up a role The second last thing is to set up a role. This role should be your base role. Create a new role like normal, but make it like a generic role. A standard role for new users. Give it permissions to access the channels that people who have reacted to the message can access. Once you have done that change the @everyone role to only have access to the channel that the message is contained in and that they can react to the message. This example it will be called Member Once you have your role done that, do the command: setuprulerole [role] So for our example it would be: setuprulerole Member Enabling / Disabling rule reaction To enable the rule reaction feature, you must have done the previous steps, after that do the command: togglerulereaction Assuming everything is correct it all should work. If a new user joins that should only have access to the channels that you specified until they react on that message with that specific emoji. If you want to disable this feature just re-run the same command again and it will be disabled!
docs.title: Rule Reaction System

docs.text: Pootis-Bot can have a custom welcome and goodbye message. Setting welcome message The welcome message is a message that is sent to a specific channel everytime a new user joins the server. To set the welcome message use the command: setupwelcomemessage [message] You would set the [message] part to your message you want to greet new users with. Example: setupwelcomemessage Hello and welcome! You can also use [user] and [server] in the message to mention the user and put in the current server name. Example: setupwelcomemessage Hello [user]! Thanks for joining [server]! Please check out the rules first then enjoy your stay This would produce something that looks like this: Setting goodbye message The goodbye message is basically exactly the same as the welcome message, except it is sent when a user leaves. To set the goodbye message use the command: setupgoodbyemessage [message] Example: setupgoodbyemessage Goodbye! Once again there is [user] but there is NO [server] Example: setupgoodbyemessage Goodbye [user]. We hope you enjoyed your stay. This would produce something that looks like this: Setting the channel Once you have your messages set its now time to set the channel they will be sent to! The base command for this is: togglewelcomemessage [channel] If this is your first time setting a welcome channel then you have to input a name. Example: togglewelcomemessage welcome This would enable the welcome and goodbye messages and set it to the channel #welcome Disabling it would also be easy, just re-run the same command but without a channel name.
docs.title: Welcome & Goodbye Message
